channel.title: NYT > U.S. News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2020 The New York Times Company

item.title: Postal Crisis Ripples Across Nation as Election Looms
item.description: President Trump’s furious objection to mail-in balloting and a new Trump-allied postmaster general are raising fears about the election and the Postal Service.
item.dc:creator: Luke Broadwater, Jack Healy, Michael D. Shear and Hailey Fuchs
item.media:credit: Michelle Gustafson for The New York Times

item.title: ‘We’re Clearly Not Doing Enough’: Drop in Testing Hampers Coronavirus Response
item.description: For the first time during the pandemic, the United States saw a downward trend in the number of coronavirus tests conducted each day.
item.dc:creator: Sarah Mervosh, Nicholas Bogel-Burroughs and Sheryl Gay Stolberg
item.media:credit: Philip Cheung for The New York Times
item.media:description: A testing site in Los Angeles on Thursday. The number of tests being conducted daily in the area is down from earlier peaks this summer.

item.title: A Bitter Wind at a Shaky Time, and Iowa Is Left Reeling
item.description: Devastating windstorms just before harvest were the last thing that Iowa farmers needed.
item.dc:creator: Will Wright
item.media:credit: Daniel Acker/Getty Images
item.media:description: Corn plants after a storm in Tama, Iowa. State officials estimate that as many as 14 million acres of farmland — more than a third of the state’s total farmland — were damaged.

item.title: Kamala Harris, Daughter of Immigrants, Is the Face of America’s Demographic Shift
item.description: Her parents’ arrival to Berkeley as young graduate students was the beginning of a historic wave of immigration from outside Europe that would change the United States in ways its leaders never imagined.
item.dc:creator: Sabrina Tavernise
item.media:credit: Erin Schaff/The New York Times
item.media:description: In California, where Kamala Harris grew up and the state she now represents in the Senate, about half of all children come from immigrant homes.

item.title: Scientists See Signs of Lasting Immunity to Covid-19, Even After Mild Infections
item.description: New research indicates that human immune system cells are storing information about the coronavirus so they can fight it off again.
item.dc:creator: Katherine J. Wu
item.media:credit: Joe Raedle/Getty Images
item.media:description: Medical workers taking a blood test for antibodies in Miami Lakes, Fla., in July.

item.title: Fire Tornadoes Reported in Northern California Wildfire
item.description: The National Weather Service issued an unusual warning on Saturday about the possibility of “a fire-induced tornado.”
item.dc:creator: Allyson Waller
item.media:credit: Katelynn Hewlett, via Reuters
item.media:description: A funnel in the Loyalton Fire in California on Saturday. Fire tornadoes spawn in a combination of extreme heat from fire, turbulent winds and uneven terrain, a meteorologist said.

item.title: Who is Louis DeJoy?
item.description: The official at the center of the controversy over the Postal Service is a major Trump donor with a career in logistics.
item.dc:creator: Lucy Tompkins
item.media:credit: Carolyn Kaster/Associated Press
item.media:description: Postmaster General Louis DeJoy, left, on Capitol Hill in August.

item.title: Milwaukee’s Lost Mega-Event: ‘It’s the Ghost Convention Now’
item.description: The Democratic convention starts Monday. But none of the leading participants will be in Milwaukee, the host city. Hotels there were closed and the bars of America’s most beer-loving city were eerily barren.
item.dc:creator: Astead W. Herndon and Reid J. Epstein
item.media:credit: Gabriela Bhaskar for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Democratic National Convention is advertised at the Miller High Life Theater in Milwaukee on Sunday.

item.title: Cincinnati Shooting Leaves 2 Dead and 9 Wounded, Police Say
item.description: It was the deadliest of four shootings late Saturday and early on Sunday. Officials said the episodes were unrelated and a motive remained unknown.
item.dc:creator: Bryan Pietsch

item.title: Pelosi to Recall House for Postal Service Vote as Democrats Press for DeJoy to Testify
item.description: The House will cut short its summer recess to consider legislation that would counter changes at the Postal Service that critics say undermine casting ballots by mail.
item.dc:creator: Emily Cochrane and Catie Edmondson
item.category: Coronavirus Aid, Relief, and Economic Security Act (2020)
item.media:credit: Michelle Gustafson for The New York Times
item.media:description: A mail delivery truck outside the post office in Darby, Pa. A series of changes enacted by Louis DeJoy, the postmaster general and a Trump megadonor, have resulted in increasing delays in delivery.

item.title: Fearing a ‘Twindemic,’ Health Experts Push Urgently for Flu Shots
item.description: There’s no vaccine for Covid-19, but there’s one for influenza. With the season’s first doses now shipping, officials are struggling over how to get people to take it.
item.dc:creator: Jan Hoffman
item.category: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
item.media:credit: Joshua Bright for The New York Times
item.media:description: A flu patient awaited treatment in a surge tent outside the emergency room of Lehigh Valley Hospital in Pennsylvania during the 2017-18 flu season.

item.title: Looming Fee Increase Could Thwart Many U.S. Citizenship Applications
item.description: The Trump administration is planning a sharp increase in the cost of naturalization this fall. Critics say it is part of a pattern intended to discourage immigration from poor nations.
item.dc:creator: Hailey Fuchs
item.media:credit: Mario Tama/Getty Images
item.media:description: A newly naturalized citizen celebrated after a drive-in ceremony in Santa Ana, Calif., last month. The Trump administration plans to raise application fees by more than 80 percent in October.

item.title: Trump’s Policies Are a Boon to the Super Rich. So Where Are All the Seven-Figure Checks?
item.description: Only a small fraction of the president’s top donors from 2016 have given as much to his re-election effort.
item.dc:creator: Glenn Thrush, Rebecca R. Ruiz and Karen Yourish
item.media:credit: Al Drago for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Trump has collected huge numbers of small donations online, but he lacks robust support from wealthy Republicans.

item.title: Dr. Jay Galst, a Specialist in Eyes and Coins, Dies at 69
item.description: An ophthalmologist with a numismatic hobby, he combined those interests in an unusual book. He died of the novel coronavirus.
item.dc:creator: Neil Genzlinger

item.title: Demonstrators plan a second protest at the postmaster general’s home.
item.dc:creator: Aishvarya Kavi
item.media:credit: Jim Lo Scalzo/EPA, via Shutterstock

item.title: A New York police union endorses Trump.
item.dc:creator: Matt Stevens
item.media:credit: Erin Schaff/The New York Times
item.media:description: President Trump speaking to the City of New York Police Benevolent Association in Bedminster, N.J., on Friday.

item.title: A New Jersey congressman is calling for an investigation into the postal crisis.
item.dc:creator: Michael Levenson
item.media:credit: T.J. Kirkpatrick for The New York Times
item.media:description: Rep. Bill Pascrell Jr. of New Jersey.

item.title: Coronavirus News: Strong Immunity May Follow Even Mild Cases
item.description: A California heat wave and power cuts create a pandemic quandary. And the C.D.C. is developing a plan for vaccine distribution.
item.media:credit: The New York Times

item.title: How Biden Could Learn From Conor Lamb’s Victory in Trump Country
item.description: Throughout his campaign, Joe Biden has repeatedly returned to the same themes and strategies that supported Mr. Lamb to a surprise victory in a district that Donald Trump carried by about 20 points in 2016.
item.dc:creator: Reid J. Epstein
item.media:credit: Ross Mantle for The New York Times
item.media:description: Representative Conor Lamb won a surprise victory in a 2018 special election in a district that President Trump carried by about 20 points in 2016.

item.title: Turning Grief for a Hidden Past Into a Healing Space
item.description: The University of Virginia in Charlottesville, designed by Thomas Jefferson, was built by enslaved people. The Memorial to Enslaved Laborers acknowledges that long-suppressed history.
item.dc:creator: Holland Cotter
item.category: Memorial to Enslaved Laborers (University of Virginia)
item.media:credit: Sanjay Suchak for The New York Times
item.media:description: The name of Isabella Gibbons, an enslaved woman who lived and worked at the University of Virginia and became a teacher.

item.title: Why A "Hidden" Trump Vote Can't Explain His Bad Poll Numbers
item.description: Republicans insist that millions of Americans want to vote for Trump but won’t admit it. Polling experts tell a different story.
item.dc:creator: Jeremy W. Peters
item.media:credit: Travis Dove for The New York Times
item.media:description: A Republican canvasser visited Tiffany Blythe in Mooresville, N.C., last month.

item.title: A Virginia House Candidate Campaigns by Attacking ‘a Man Dressed as a Woman’
item.description: As Bob Good, an opponent of same-sex marriage, tries to rally Republicans with attacks on transgender rights, Democrats see an opening in the G.O.P.-held district.
item.dc:creator: Stephanie Saul
item.media:credit: Amy Friedenberger/The Roanoke Times, via Associated Press
item.media:description: After ousting a Republican incumbent, Bob Good will face the Democratic candidate, Cameron Webb, in the general election.

item.title: Rapid Testing is at Parties, Concerts and Hotels. Social Distance Still Required.
item.description: Determined to proceed with parties and events this summer, hosts are adding screenings at the door. But such measures are hardly a guarantee of safety, medical experts warn.
item.dc:creator: Alyson Krueger
item.media:credit: Joe Carrotta for The New York Times
item.media:description: Rite of nasal passage: Amanda Seekamp, who is in charge of guest relations at the Surf Lodge in Montauk, N.Y.., gets a rapid test from Dr. Seth Gordon, a private doctor working in Montauk.

item.title: Trump Says He’ll Look Into a Pardon for Edward Snowden
item.description: The remarks seemed to be a shift for President Trump, who repeatedly called Mr. Snowden a “traitor” and “spy who should be executed” in the years before his election.
item.dc:creator: Aishvarya Kavi
item.media:credit: Kayana Szymczak for The New York Times
item.media:description: Edward Snowden spoke at M.I.T. from exile in Moscow in 2016.

item.title: Robert Trump, the President’s Younger Brother, Dies at 71
item.description: A loyal spokesman for the family, he shunned the spotlight and had “zero sense of entitlement.”
item.dc:creator: Annie Karni
item.media:credit: Diane Bondaress/Associated Press
item.media:description: Robert Trump, left, with the future president at a society event in 1999.

item.title: 9/11 Light Tribute to Shine After All, Officials Say
item.description: The National September 11 Memorial & Museum had said the display would have to be canceled because of the coronavirus pandemic.
item.dc:creator: Aimee Ortiz
item.media:credit: Kirsten Luce for The New York Times
item.media:description: The tribute features 88 specially made lights used to create the projections that tower over the city until dawn on Sept. 12.

item.title: Georgia Trooper Is Charged in Fatal Shooting of Black Driver
item.description: The trooper, who is white, was fired and charged with murder a week after the killing, which happened after the driver had been pulled over for having a broken taillight, the authorities said.
item.dc:creator: Allyson Waller
item.media:credit: Georgia Department of Public Safety, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Jacob G. Thompson, who had been a Georgia state trooper since 2013, was fired and charged with felony murder and aggravated assault on Friday.
